bibl.title: Letter from Carlos J. Finlay to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 21, 1908

div1.p: Finlay outlines measures taken to ensure that a case of yellow fever, in Havana, does not develop into an epidemic.

div1.head: Letter from Carlos J. Finlay to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 21, 1908
div1.opener:
AL CONTESTA CONSIGNECA PECHA Y NUMERO DE
ESTA COMUNICACION
EN CABA
República de Cuba
-------
Departamento Nacional de Sanidad
-------
JEFATURA
-------
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
Habana, September 21st. 1908.
My dear Major Kean:
div1.p:
You will have received by this time all
the clinical data and summery of the autopsy findings con-
cerning the case of Sueido.

Last saturday my whole morning was taken
up in making a careful inspection of all the fumigation work
done in the suspected zone, accompanied by Dr. Guiteras and
Dr. Lopez del Valle. The result was very satisfactory and we
ascertained besides that Sueido on one of the possible incu-
bation days had been on board one of Herrera's fruit stea-
mers which ply between Havana, Antilla and Daiquiri. Dr. Hu-
go Roberts has been therefore instructed to have that boat
fumigated the next time they return to Havana.

The prophylactic measures taken for Suei-
ro's case have been the following:

1st...Fumigation of the blocks in which
“La Perla” and “Cuatro Naciones” are located, as well as
the contigious ones. Notwithstanding the fact that those
particular Fèndas had been previously fumigated (on general
principalsles) the preceding week.

2nd...Temperatures of all nonimmunes
within the suspected zone taken twice a day by Inspectors
of the Department.

3rd...Inspection and petriolization of
all the blocks within the old city limits, that is, between
the western boundary line formed by Egido and Nonserrate
streets and the seashore.

4th...Vagrants without work or home
found in the suspected zone, are taken up and sent to Tris-
Maj. Kean. (2)
cornia for five days' observation, being maintained there
at our expense. Approval from the Provisional Governor
having been obtained.

5th...Reminders have been sent to all
the Havana physicians demanding prompt notification of non-
immunes with Dengue or any other fever when the diagnosis
of yellow fever cannot be excluded within the first twenty-
four hours of their illness.

By my letter to Dr. Amesse dated the
19th. inst. of which a copy is herein enclosed, you will
see how it was that the quarantine was understood to have
been declared against all ports in Cuba, and with it you
will find a copy of our protest.

Dr. Birmingham in reply to my inqui-
ries, has ordered the following:

“A period of nineteen days having e-
"lapsed since the onset in the case of yellow fever recent-
"ly occurring in Havana, I have today recommended that the
"restrictions against the enlisted men of this Army visiting
QHavana (Officers have not been restricted) be removed”-

I have today reminded him that Sueiro's
invasion was the 7th. inst..

No new case or suspect has occurred
in this part of the Island, but today a suspect has been
notified at Holguin and Dr. Lebredo starts to night to exa-
mine the patient. I shall cable the result of his investi-
gation.

I have requested Dr. Thomason to delay
his return to Santiago untill Lebredo's report and he has
readily agreed to do so and he has written to Dr. Fauntle-
roy informing him about this. If as I expect the case at
Holguin proves negative of yellow fever, I am thinking of
giving to Dr. Fauntleroy again the direction of the mos-
quito campaign in Havana. Dr. Church has been poorly with
an abcess in the right arm which prevents him from attend-
ing to this matter. Dr. Lopez del Valle has been receiving
Maj. Kean (3)
the inspections, daily reports and a couple of days ago I had
a talk with the Special Inspectors endeavoring to rouse their
ennergies in view of the present situation. I think that our
prospects of having no other cases of yellow fever are very
fair, every one in the Department having taken a lively in-
terest in the matter
September 22nd.

Your letter of 18th. inst. just received. General
O'reilly's recommendations are already in operation and your own
will be carefully attended to.

I regret to say that my congratulations about
my dictation are premature for I have not tried it yet.

Mrs. Ratcliff leaves today on the Transport to
complete her vacation in the U. S.

Please remember me kindly to General O'reilly and
to our Cuban members at the Congress and believe me yours very
faithful,
div1.closer:
Carlos J. Finlay Major J. R. Kean.
War Office Surgeon General's Office.
Washington, D. C.
P. S.
